space.arim.universal.util.concurrent

Interface EnhancedExecutor

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Executor

    public interface EnhancedExecutor
extends Executor
    A Executor with upgraded concurrent functionality. Focuses specifically on concurrent execution and scheduling, as such there are no methods for thread pool management (such as shutdown, await termination, etc.) as in ExecutorService.

    decorate(Executor) may be used to enhance a Executor into a EnhancedExecutor.

    Specifications:
    * Requires Executor.execute(Runnable)
    * EnhancedExecutor provides default implementations for all of its own specifications.

    Qualities:

    Adds submit(Runnable) and supply(Supplier) for basic asynchronous work.

    Adds several scheduling methods to enable timed execution. Programmers may, if desired, dynamically provide the time between executions based on a delay function.
    Scheduling comes in many variants. schedule(Runnable, long, TimeUnit) may be used for a one-off delayed task (delays and then fires once, without repeating).

    There are several variant methods, which follow schedule(Runnable/Consumer, long, LongUnaryOperator/LongBinaryOperator, TimeUnit), which allow for repeating delayed tasks.
    The Runnable is the execution to run, or a Consumer if the task must be able to access itself. The long is the initial delay. If negative, nothing happens and all further scheduling is cancelled. If zero, task eexecution begins immediately.
    The LongUnaryOperator or LongBinaryOperator is the delay function used to calculate the delay before the next execution. All executions are guaranteed not to overlap. This is ensured in the default implementation and should likewise be upheld in overriding implementations.
    If the delay function is "Unary", it takes the last delay as the input; "Unary" delay functions calculate the next delay based only on the previous delay. If "Binary", the delay function takes the last delay as the left input and the last execution time as the right input. Essentially, "Binary" delay functions generate the next delay based on the previous delay and the execution time. For simple implementations, DelayFunctions may be used.
    The TimeUnit is the unit which the initial delay is specified in and the unit which the delay function uses. However, note that while TimeUnit.NANOSECONDS is a possible parameter, implementations are not guaranteed further precision than milliseconds time.
    The method variants are: (schedule(Runnable, long, LongUnaryOperator, TimeUnit) / schedule(Consumer, long, LongUnaryOperator, TimeUnit) / schedule(Runnable, long, LongBinaryOperator, TimeUnit) / schedule(Consumer, long, LongBinaryOperator, TimeUnit)).
    Author:
    A248

      • Methods inherited from interface java.util.concurrent.Executor

        execute

    • Method Detail

      • submit

        default CompletableFuture<Void> submit(Runnable command)
        Execute an asynchronous action.
        Differs from Executor.execute(java.lang.Runnable) in that the returned CompletableFuture provides additional functionality, including the ability to listen for completion or block until complete.
        Parameters:
        command - the Runnable to run
        Returns:
        a CompletableFuture which will return null on Future.get()

      • supply

        default <T> CompletableFuture<T> supply(Supplier<T> supplier)
        Supplies a value asynchronously. Similar to ExecutorService.submit(Callable).
        However, Callable may throw an exception, while Supplier does not.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the supplier
        Parameters:
        supplier - the supplier
        Returns:
        a CompletableFuture

      • schedule

        default Task schedule(Runnable cmd,
                      long delay,
                      TimeUnit units)
        Schedules a one-shot delayed task.
        The returned Task may be used to cancel execution if it has not yet started.

        Note that there is no schedule(Consumer, long, TimeUnit) method. This is because the task consumer, should the task consumer cancel the task, there will be no effect, as the execution will already have begun.

        Parameters:
        cmd - the Runnable to run
        delay - the delay duration. If negative, nothing happens and all further scheduling is cancelled; if positive, run immediately.
        units - the time units of the delay
        Returns:
        a Task which may be cancelled, never null

      • schedule

        default Task schedule(Runnable cmd,
                      long initialDelay,
                      LongUnaryOperator delayFunction,
                      TimeUnit units)
        Schedules a repeating task where further delays are calculated after each execution by the provided function.
        The delay function is invoked after each execution with the last delay as the input.

        Use DelayFunctions for default implementations of delay functions.
        Parameters:
        cmd - the Runnable to run
        initialDelay - the initial delay duration. If negative, nothing happens and all further scheduling is cancelled; if positive, run immediately.
        delayFunction - the function to use when calculating the next delay
        units - the time units the initialDelay and delayFunction use
        Returns:
        a Task which may then be cancelled, never null

      • schedule

        default Task schedule(Consumer<Task> cmd,
                      long initialDelay,
                      LongUnaryOperator delayFunction,
                      TimeUnit units)
        Schedules a repeating task where further delays are calculated after each execution by the provided function.

        Differs from schedule(Runnable, long, LongUnaryOperator, TimeUnit) in that it accepts a Consumer which may be used to cancel further scheduling of the task from within the execution itself.
        Parameters:
        cmd - the Consumer to accept the Task, which may then be cancelled
        initialDelay - the initial delay duration. If negative, nothing happens and all further scheduling is cancelled; if positive, run immediately.
        delayFunction - the function to use when calculating the next delay
        units - the time units the initialDelay and delayFunction use
        Returns:
        the same Task the Consumer received, never null

      • schedule

        default Task schedule(Runnable cmd,
                      long initialDelay,
                      LongBinaryOperator delayFunction,
                      TimeUnit units)
        Schedules a repeating task where further delays are calculated after each execution by the provided function.
        The delay function is invoked after each execution with the last delay, the left input, and the last execution time, the right input.

        Use DelayFunctions for default implementations of delay functions.
        Parameters:
        cmd - the Runnable to run
        initialDelay - the initial delay duration. If negative, nothing happens and all further scheduling is cancelled; if positive, run immediately.
        delayFunction - the function to use when calculating the next delay
        units - the time units the initialDelay and delayFunction use
        Returns:
        a Task which may then be cancelled, never null

      • schedule

        default Task schedule(Consumer<Task> cmd,
                      long initialDelay,
                      LongBinaryOperator delayFunction,
                      TimeUnit units)
        Schedules a repeating task where further delays are calculated after each execution by the provided function.

        Differs from schedule(Runnable, long, LongBinaryOperator, TimeUnit) in that it accepts a Consumer which may be used to cancel further scheduling of the task from within the execution itself.
        Parameters:
        cmd - the Consumer to accept the Task, which may then be cancelled
        initialDelay - the initial delay duration. If negative, nothing happens and all further scheduling is cancelled; if positive, run immediately.
        delayFunction - the function to use when calculating the next delay
        units - the time units the initialDelay and delayFunction use
        Returns:
        the same Task the Consumer received, never null

      • decorate

        static EnhancedExecutor decorate(Executor executor)
        Enhances a Executor, converting to an EnhancedExecutor.
        The result uses the default implementations of all but the required execute().
        Parameters:
        executor - the executor
        Returns:
        an EnhancedExecutor with the same Executor.execute(Runnable) method
